explanation.body:
$\textbf{1.) Capsular Space of Bowman's Capsule}$
This is where the path of filtrate through the nephron starts, right after passing through the glomerular filtration membrane. 

$\textbf{2.) Proximal Convoluted Tubule}$
Filtrate moves directly from the capsular space into the PCT. "Proximal" indicates that it's closer to the capsule where the filtrate's journey starts. 

$\textbf{3.) Loop of Henle (Nephron Loop) }$
From the PCT, filtrate moves down through the loop of Henle, where water is reabsorbed and the filtrate is concentrated. 

$\textbf{4.) Distal Convoluted Tubule}$
After the loop of Henle, filtrate moves into the DCT.

$\textbf{5.) Collecting Duct}$
Here, the filtrate become urine. The CD collects urine from multiple nephrons and moves it down into the renal pelvis. From there, the ureters move the urine to the bladder.


\pic{"url": "https://i.imgur.com/lIqjPwp.png", "alt": "alt goes here", "maxHeight": "500"}

The myogenic mechanism of renal autoregulation helps the kidney maintain a stable glomerular filtration rate (GFR) despite changes in blood pressure. It's an intrinsic mechanism, which means its maintained by the kidney and its effects are local. Here's how it works: 

$\textbf{1.) Blood Pressure Changes}$  
When blood pressure (BP) increases, it exerts a greater force on the walls of the afferent arteriole. 

$\textbf{2.) Smooth Muscle Response}$  
Smooth muscle cells have a tendency to contract when stretched. In response to the stretch caused by the increased BP, the smooth muscle in the walls of the arteriole contract, constricting the diameter of the afferent arteriole.

$\textbf{3.) Decrease in GFR}$
The constricted afferent arteriole decreases the amount of blood reaching the glomerulus. The pressure inside the glomerulus is decreased, and the GFR as well. 



So, overall, when BP increases, GFR increases. The myogenic mechanism compensates for this and prevents damage to the glomerulus from a GFR that is too high.

Tubular reabsorption is the process by which water and solutes are reclaimed from the filtrate and returned to blood by peritubular capillaries. 

Tubular secretion, on the other hand, is the process by which substances are moved from blood into filtrate. Tubular secretion is different from glomerular filtration as it occurs later on in the nephron. Some substances can't pass through the glomerular filtration membrane, but still need to be excreted. They can be selectively moved into the filtrate by tubular secretion.

$\textbf{Structure 1}$ 
The Renal corpuscle. The glomerulus is located here, where filtration occurs. 

$\textbf{Structure 2}$ 
The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), where tubular reabsorption takes place to reclaim things such as glucose, amino acids, and sodium. Water tends to follow sodium by osmosis, so about 65% of filtered water is also reabsorbed here.  

$\textbf{Structure 3}$ 
The nephron loop (loop of Henle), which is responsible for creating an osmotic gradient that helps conserve water and concentrate urine. This gradient is created by the countercurrent multiplier mechanism. 

$\textbf{Structure 4}$ 
The distal convoluted tubule, which plays a role the reabsorption of sodium ions. It is $\underline{not}$ responsible for reabsorbing approximately 65% of filtered water and sodium and all the filtered amino acids and glucose. This happens in the PCT.

$\textbf{Structure 5}$ 
The collecting duct, which is indeed relatively impermeable to water and solutes without the influence of hormones. The primary hormones that influence the CD are aldosterone and anti-diuretic hormone (ADH).

\pic{"url": "https://i.imgur.com/DubnOhu.png", "alt": "alt goes here", "maxHeight": "200"}

Rhabdomyolysis (Rhabdo) is a condition in which skeletal muscle tissue breaks down and releases its component proteins and electrolytes into the bloodstream. One of these proteins is myoglobin, which is responsible for storing oxygen in the muscle. 

The myoglobin is filtered by the glomerulus and excreted out in the urine. It gives the urine a cola color. 

Red urine might indicate blood (hematuria) which is often a result of trauma, urinary tract infection (UTI), or kidney stones. 

Green urine may be the result of a contrast medium administered for imaging scans.

Pale yellow is the normal color of urine. The color comes from the presence of urobilin (urochrome), which is a result of the breakdown of hemoglobin.

Hematuria is the presence of blood in the urine. The word can be broken down into its component parts. 

$\textbf{Hemat/o-}$: pertaining to blood 

$\textbf{-Uria}$: condition of urine

The parasympathetic (rest and digest) nervous system enables the bladder to empty by activation of M3 receptors.

The parasympathetic nervous system (PSNS) is responsible for the emptying of the bladder. The PSNS is also known as the rest and digest system, and it's generally responsible for relaxing the body after times of stress and regulating digestion and urination. In contrast, the sympathetic nervous system (SNS) is active in times of stress and danger. It is commonly known as the fight or flight system. The two systems typically have opposite functions of each other. In times of stress and danger, the body wants to conserve energy and be ready for anything. That's why urination is mediated by the PSNS and not the SNS. 

Muscarinic receptors are typically associated with the PSNS, while beta-adrenergic receptors are typically associated with the SNS.

The process of micturition occurs via the micturition reflex. While this process is mostly mediated by the parasympathetic nervous system, there is some voluntary control via the somatic nervous system. 

There's three primary muscles involved in urination.

$\textbf{1.) Detrusor}$ 
The detrusor is under the control of the autonomic nervous system. Parasympathetic stimulation leads to contraction, which helps expel urine, while sympathetic stimulation does the opposite.

$\textbf{2.) Internal Urethral Sphincter}$
Also a smooth muscle, also under autonomic control. Here the sympathetic nervous system stimulates contraction, which holds urine in. Parasympathetic innervation has the opposite effect. 

$\textbf{3.) External Urethral Sphincter}$
This is a skeletal muscle, under voluntary control by the somatic nervous system.  It's essentially the last line of defense from the release of urine.

Aldosterone acts on the principle cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct to increase the reabsorption of sodium (Na$^{+}$). Water follows sodium by osmosis, so the net result is that we retain water. 

Aldosterone, Natriuretic peptide, and Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) are the major hormones that affect fluid balance. 

$\textbf{Aldosterone}$
Increases Na$^{+}$ reabsorption → Water follows (retain water)
Remember ald$\textit{o}$sterone and s$\textit{o}$dium. Or, if it helps, al$\textit{dos}$terone is $\textit{sod}$ium backwards.

$\textbf{Natriuretic peptide}$
Increases Na$^{+}$ secretion → Water follows (lose water)
Remember $\textit{Na}$triuretic peptide and $\textit{Na+}$

$\textbf{Antidiuretic Hormone}$
Places aquaporins in collecting duct for water to be reabsorbed. 
Remember ADH = Always Digging Holes. Holes = Aquaporins

When it comes to water balance disorders, its important to think about what's happening to Na$^{+}$ as well as what's happening to the water. 

$\textbf{Volume excess}$
Everything is retained. Na$^{+}$ and water. The ECF remains isotonic. 

$\textbf{Hypotonic hydration}$
Water is retained but Na$^{+}$ is excreted. This leads to more water than solute throughout the body, resulting in a diluted (hypotonic) ECF. 

$\textbf{Volume depletion (hypovolemia)}$
Na$^{+}$ and water are both lost in proportionate amounts. Even though volume is lost, the concentrations stay the same, so the ECF is isotonic. 

$\textbf{Dehydration}$
More water than Na$^{+}$ is lost. This concentrates the ECF (hypertonic). 

Aldosterone increases Na$^{+}$ reabsorption and water follows the Na$^{+}$ by osmosis. So, an excess of aldosterone secretion will lead to volume excess, because both water and sodium are retained.

Increased plasma osmolality is when the plasma (ECF) has a higher concentration of solutes due to less fluid. 

In this case, we would $\textit{not}$ want to inhibit ADH secretion. ADH secretion will help us hold on to fluid, so we would not want to inhibit this. Similarly, we would not want to decrease water reabsorption. 

Water diuresis refers to the excretion of more water, which again, is not what we want. 

Production of hypertonic urine on the other hand, is an appropriate response in this situation. Hypertonic urine is more concentrated (less water). This means that the body is holding on to as much water as possible, in an effort to lower the plasma osmolality as much as possible.

Angiotensin II is a hormone that helps increase blood pressure and fluid volume. It works by promoting vasoconstriction, retaining Na$^{+}$ + water, and stimulates release of ADH and aldosterone.

I like to remember angiotensin's function by remembering: Angio$\textit{tens}$in II increases blood pressure by $\textit{tensing}$ the vessels (and retaining volume as well as releasing ADH and aldosterone) 

Angiotensin II pretty much does all the things. 

Angiotensin II is formed as a result of the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone-System (RAAS). 

Here's how RAAS works: 

$\textbf{1.) Stimulus}$
Decrease in BP → Decrease in GFR. The juxtaglomerular cells detect the decrease in GFR and release renin, an enzyme. 

$\textbf{2.) Angiotensinogen → Angiotensin I (via Renin)}$
Renin converts angiotensinogen, which is a plasma protein produced by the liver, to angiotensin I. 

$\textbf{3.) Angiotensin I → Angiotensin II (via ACE)}$
Angiotensin I is converted to its active form, angiotensin II, by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE).

The kidneys play a predominant role in regulating the blood bicarbonate (HCO$_{3}$$^{-}$) concentration and the metabolic component of acid-base balance.

$\textbf{Bicarbonate}$

Bicarbonate is a crucial buffer in the body. It helps maintain the pH balance of the blood. Bicarbonate is formed through this reaction, catalyzed by carbonic anhydrase:

CO$_{2 }$ + H$_{2}$O ⇌ H$_{2}$CO$_{3}$ ⇌ HCO$_{3}$- + H$^{+}$

$\textbf{Kidney Regulation of Bicarbonate}$

The kidneys can help regulate bicarbonate concentrations in the proximal convoluted tubule. In the tubular filtrate, carbonic anhydrase converts H$_{2}$CO$_{3}$ to CO$_{2 }$ + H$_{2}$O, and the CO$_{2 }$ then enters the tubular cell. In the cell, it again reacts with water and carbonic anhydrase to form H$_{2}$CO$_{3}$, which dissociates to form HCO$_{3}$- + H$^{+}$. The H$^{+}$ is sent back into the tubular fluid by the Na$^{+}$/H$^{+}$ antiporter, while the HCO$_{3}$- goes to the blood plasma. 

By controlling the reabsorption of bicarbonate ions, the kidneys can adjust the blood bicarbonate concentration to compensate for any acid-base disturbances, particularly the metabolic component. 

$\textbf{The Lungs}$

While the lungs do play a major role in acid-base balance, they do so by controlling the concentration of CO$_{2}$. CO$_{2}$ goes on to become H$_{2}$CO$_{3}$ (carbonic acid), so regulating the amount of CO$_{2}$ does affect pH, but not specifically of blood bicarbonate levels, which is what this question is asking.

The respiratory system compensates for changes in pH by adjusting the levels of CO$_{2}$.  CO$_{2}$ in the body becomes H$_{2}$CO$_{3}$ (carbonic acid). By blowing off more CO$_{2}$, the body is able to decrease the concentration of H$_{2}$CO$_{3}$, raising the pH, and vice versa. 

$\textbf{Respiratory Compensation for Acidosis}$
If the pH is too low, the body can start breathing faster and deeper to blow off more CO$_{2}$ and compensate. 

$\textbf{Respiratory Compensation for Alkalosis }$
If the pH is too high, the body can slow down the respiratory rate and depth, in an effort to hold on to more CO$_{2}$ and lower the pH.

Hyperventilation is when you breath faster and deeper than normal. It's common during panic attacks. When you hyperventilate, you exchange more air than normal, which means you eliminate more CO$_{2}$ than normal. 

As you blow off more CO$_{2}$, the  concentration of H$_{2}$CO$_{3}$ (carbonic acid) starts to drop. This leads to an increase in pH, as the blood is becoming less acidic and therefore more basic. 

This happens because when CO$_{2}$ comes into contact with H$_{2}$O, it becomes H$_{2}$CO$_{3}$ in a reaction catalyzed by the enzyme carbonic anhydrase. So, eliminating CO$_{2}$ means it can never react with the H$_{2}$O to form H$_{2}$CO$_{3}$.

CO$_{2 }$ + H$_{2}$O ⇌ H$_{2}$CO$_{3}$ ⇌ HCO$_{3}$- + H$^{+}$

Looking at the pH before anything else can tell us if the patient is in a form of acidosis or alkalosis, and can help us rule out two answer choices right away. 

A pH of 7.66 is above the upper limit for normal, so this patient is in some form of alkalosis, either respiratory or metabolic.  

Looking at the pCO$_{2}$, we can see that it's within normal range so we can rule out respiratory alkalosis.

That leaves metabolic alkalosis as the last option, and looking at the HCO$_{3}$-  concentration, we can confirm. 33 mmol/L is above the upper limit for normal. This indicates that we have a greater concentration of a base which further supports that the patient is in metabolic alkalosis.

The kidney compensates for respiratory acidosis by increasing rate of H$^{+}$ secretion into the tubular fluid. Increasing H$^{+}$ secretion is a great way for the kidneys to get rid of acid in an attempt to compensate. 

Decreasing the number of phosphate ions reabsorbed would not help compensate for acidosis. Phosphate ions can act as a buffer inside the cell to help balance out changes in pH, so decreasing reabsorption is the opposite of what we want. 

Producing alkaline urine would indicate that the body was reabsorbing more H$^{+}$, which would only worsen acidosis. 

Increasing the volume of urine produced would not compensate for acid-base disorders.

The process that involves alternating waves of smooth muscle contraction that helps move food down the esophagus is called peristalsis. 

Segmentation consists of rhythmic contraction and relaxation in the digestive tract to help mix food with intestinal secretions. Segmentation does not result in the movement of food - only the mixing. 

Mass movements are large, slow contractions of the colon to move the undigested waste towards the rectum for defecation. 

Mastication is the process of chewing. 

\pic{"url": "https://i.imgur.com/vAQ26v9.png", "alt": "alt goes here", "maxHeight": "300"}

The mucosa, submucosa, muscularis, and serosa are all layers of digestive tract organs. 

The glandulosa is not an actual layer, but glands are found in the submucosa.

The myenteric plexus is a network of nerve fibers and ganglia between the longitudinal and circular muscle layers of the digestive organs that form part of the enteric nervous system.

 Breaking the word down into it's component parts gives several clues as to what it is: 

$\textbf{My/o-}$
Refers to muscle tissue

$\textbf{Enter/o}$
Refers to the intestine

$\textbf{-Ic}$
Pertaining to 

$\textbf{Plexus}$
A bundle of nerves

So, a network of nerves that are associated with muscle tissue in the intestine.

Enamel is the outermost layer of a tooth's crown. It's a hard, mineralized, non-living substance composed primarily of hydroxyapatite crystals. 

\pic{"url": "https://i.imgur.com/oagqgIu.png", "alt": "alt goes here", "maxHeight": "300"}
\pic{"url": "https://i.imgur.com/JwXoTyp.png", "alt": "alt goes here", "maxHeight": "500"}

The pancreas secretes a bicarbonate rich fluid called pancreatic juice into the $\textit{duodenum}$, not the stomach. That being said, the other options are all valid mechanisms to protect the stomach from the acidic environment.

$\textbf{Tight junctions between epithelial cells}$
This helps prevent acid from seeping in between the epithelial cells and damaging underlying tissues. Without them, acid would be able to get around the epithelial cells and wreak havoc.

$\textbf{Frequent replacement of damaged epithelial cells by stem cells}$
This helps ensure that the epithelial barrier stays healthy and protective. 

$\textbf{Mucous coat}$
Epithelial and glandular cells in the stomach wall secrete the mucous coat, which contains bicarbonate to help neutralize stomach acid.

Cholecystokinin is the hormone secreted by duodenal cells that triggers the contraction of the gallbladder. 

Breaking cholecystokinin into its component roots can help you remember its function: 

$\textbf{Cholecyst/o-}$ 
This term means gallbladder. It can actually be broken down further to chole-, which means bile, and cyst/o, which means sac. 

$\textbf{-Kinin}$
This suffix means "to move". 

So, directly translated, cholecystokinin means to "move the bile sac".  This reflects its key function in digestion, which is to stimulate the gallbladder to contract and release bile.
\pic{"url": "https://i.imgur.com/BKe18iE.png", "alt": "alt goes here", "maxHeight": "600"}

The small intestine does not contain the highest concentration of enteric bacteria. While the small intestine does contain some bacteria, the highest concentration is found in the large intestine (roughly 800 species). 

The bacteria in the large intestine help further break down food, synthesize vitamins (some B and K), protect epithelial cells, stimulate the immune system, and prevent overgrowth of harmful bacteria.

Goblet cells are specialized epithelial cells found in the intestinal mucosa. They are responsible for producing and secreting mucus, which helps lubricate and protect the rest of the epithelium.

Enterocytes help digest and absorb nutrients. 

Paneth cells help protect from microbes. 

Peyer's patches are sections of lymphoid tissue found in the small intestine.
\pic{"url": "https://i.imgur.com/JOIjjBU.png", "alt": "alt goes here", "maxHeight": "600"}

The colon's main function is to absorb water and to compact intestinal contents into feces. 

The gallbladder stores and release bile produced by the liver. 

The pylorus is a muscular region of the stomach near the small intestine. 

The antrum is the lower portion of the stomach, between the body and the pylorus.
The defecation reflex is triggered by the stimulation of stretch receptors in the rectum. These receptors are stimulated by the distention of the rectum by the feces.

Fat soluble vitamins can be stored in the body's fat reserves and can accumulate over time. Water soluble vitamins, however, can be easily excreted in the urine. 

The fat soluble vitamins are: Vitamins A, D, E, K

After fat digestion and micelle formation, fatty acids and monoglycerides are absorbed by enterocytes. Inside the enterocyte, these are converted to triglycerides, which are then coated by proteins to form chylomicrons.

Chylomicrons do not contain the most protein of any lipoprotein. HDL contains the most. 

Chylomicrons are too large to penetrate the walls of capillaries, but not lacteals. 

The core of chylomicrons consists of triglycerides, not proteins. Proteins coat the outside.

Luteinizing hormone (LH) is released by the anterior pituitary in response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH).

\textit{\textbf{L}}H then acts on \textit{\textbf{L}}eydig to release testosterone (remember L acts on L to secrete T). 

Follicle-stimulating hormone (F\textit{\textbf{S}}H) is also released by the anterior pituitary in response to GnRH, but acts on \textit{\textbf{S}}ertoli cells to stimulate \textit{\textbf{s}}perm production.
\pic{"url": "https://i.imgur.com/H8arhKl.png", "alt": "alt goes here", "maxHeight": "600"}

Erection is controlled by the parasympathetic division of the autonomic nervous system, not the sympathetic. Here's how the process of erection works:

\underline{\textbf{We need to relax smooth muscle → fill with blood}}
In order to have an erection, the corpora cavernosa sinusoids in the penis must fill with blood. 

To do this, the parasympathetic nervous system stimulates relaxation of cavernosal smooth muscle cells to allow more blood in. 

\underline{\textbf{How do we relax the actually smooth muscle? (NO-cGMP pathway)}}
Nitric oxide (NO) is released from nerve endings and endothelial cells. The NO enters the cell and activates the enzyme guanylate cyclase, which produces cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). 

The cGMP simulates a protein kinase that decreases intracellular calcium concentration. This all results in smooth muscle relaxation.

The menstrual phase is the first phase of the menstrual cycle. It occurs when a fertilized egg is not implanted, and hormonal changes trigger the shedding of the uterine lining. 

The inner lining of the uterus, the endometrium, has two layers. 

The functional layer is the top layer that thickens during the follicular phase, in preparation for pregnancy. If pregnancy doesn't occur, the layer is shedded during menstruation. 

The basal layer sits between the functional layer and the myometrium. It doesn't get shed, and is responsible for the regeneration of the functional layer.

Oogenesis starts before birth. All primary oocytes start meiosis I, but stop at prophase I. 

Once a month, just before ovulation, meiosis I resumes. 

After ovulation, the secondary oocyte starts meiosis II, but stops at metaphase II, unless fertilization occurs.

If fertilization occurs, meiosis II continues and ootids are formed.

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), is a hormone produced by the developing placenta. 

It plays a crucial role in supporting the corpus luteum, a temporary structure in the ovary that continues to produce progesterone, which is essential for maintaining the uterine lining and supporting early pregnancy.  Without hCG, the corpus luteum will start to break down after ovulation. 

 hCG is also the primary hormone detected in most pregnancy tests.

During parturition, oxytocin stimulates the smooth muscle cells in the myometrium (muscular layer of the uterus) to contract. These contractions become progressively stronger and more frequent as labor progresses, helping to push the baby down the birth canal.

As oxytocin stimulates contractions, the stretching and pressure on the cervix caused by these contractions further triggers the release of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary gland. This creates a positive feedback loop, leading to stronger and more frequent contractions, ultimately expelling the baby.

While estrogen helps prepare the uterus for childbirth, oxytocin doesn't directly affect the number of estrogen receptors. 

Prostaglandins help soften and thin the cervix during labor to allow the baby to pass through. Oxytocin works alongside prostaglandins, not against them.
While mammary glands do undergo some development throughout life, full maturation for milk production only happens in the presence of hormonal changes during pregnancy.

Epithelial cells lining the intestine come from the endoderm, not the ectoderm.

The endoderm is the innermost germ layer and gives rise to the lining of the digestive tract (including the intestine), as well as the respiratory system epithelium and some glands.
The umbilical cord serves as the connection between the fetus and the placenta. It allows for the transfer of oxygen and nutrients from the maternal circulation into fetal circulation.

As we age, our arteries actually get stiffer. 

This actually contributes to generally higher blood pressures in the elderly, as the walls of the vascular are no longer as elastic and able to stretch as much. Because they lose this ability, the diameter of the vessel remains narrower, which contributes to a higher pressure.
